kszucs opened a new pull request #8288:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8288


   Expose `EqualOptions` and set nans_equal to False. We should probably reduce `Array::Equals` to data structure equality and move the ArrayEquals implementation to the comparison kernels.

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #8288:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8288#issuecomment-701364460


   > Expose EqualOptions and set nans_equal to False.
   
   The code actually sets it to True, not False (meaning that `equals` will return True if NaNs are at the same location)
   
   But so that means we change the behaviour again? Because ARROW-6043 reported that it changed from True to False (which is the behaviour on master as well)

kszucs closed pull request #8288: ARROW-6043: [Python] Array equals returns incorrectly if NaNs are in arrays
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8288

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
{code:python}
import numpy as np
import pyarrow as pa

data = [0, 1, np.nan, None, 4]

arr1 = pa.array(data)
arr2 = pa.array(data)

pa.Array.equals(arr1, arr2)
{code}

Unsure if this is expected behavior, but in Arrow 0.12.1 this returned `True` as compared to `False` in 0.14.1.
fields.summary: [Python] Array equals returns incorrectly if NaNs are in arrays

comments.body: Somewhat surprised by this. Can you submit a PR?
Will try to find some time to throw in a PR once our build issues are resolved :)

How is this surprising? It's well-known (well, perhaps not :-)) that NaNs compare unequal to themselves. Numpy behaves similarly:
{code:python}
>>> a = np.array([1.0, np.nan])                                                                                                                                      
>>> a == a                                                                                                                                                           
array([ True, False])
>>> (a == a).all()                                                                                                                                                   
False
{code}

In other words, Arrow was previously incorrect and it was fixed.

I think this is even less of a problem in Arrow than Numpy, because a missing value in Arrow is represented as a None (which compares equal to itself), so the only reason to have a NaN in Arrow data should be when you really need to represent floating-point NaN.

This is true -- I think we might need to think about semantic array equality (according to type-specific comparison rules) versus memory equality (i.e. what does `memcmp` on each non-null value yield). Both have their use cases I suppose

For context, the source of us finding this bug was we were using this function within cuDF unit tests to check for correct null vs NaN handling behavior. I agree this makes sense to return false, but a function that does memory comparison as opposed to value comparison would be useful.

We worked around this today by unsafe typecasting from float to int for now which effectively turns it into a memory comparison.

Actually, if you look on the C++ side (see `cpp/src/arrow/compare.h`), the equality comparisons now take an optional `EqualOptions` where you can choose to set `nans_equal` to true.

So I would suggest to also expose those parameters in Python. Perhaps like it is done in CSV (see _csv.pyx).

For reference, here's how R handles this:
{code:java}
$ R 
> a <- c(1, NA, 3, 4) 
> b <- c(1, NA, 3, 4) 
> a == b 
[1] TRUE   NA TRUE TRUE 
> all(a == b) 
[1] NA 
> all(a == b, na.rm = TRUE) 
[1] TRUE
> identical(a, b) 
[1] TRUE
{code}
"array equals" is a vectorized operation, so you get an array back. NA == NA is itself NA (because since the data is missing, we don't know what it is, so logically we also don't know if they're equal). If you want the scalar version, you can do the equivalent to what Antoine showed in Numpy with all(), but note that all() returns *NA* here, not FALSE, for the same reason as the scalar comparison. all() (along with many other base R aggregation functions) does take a na.rm argument though, so you can do the test only on the non-missing values.

identical() does the object comparison and shows the arrays to be the same, despite the missing data semantics. 

At the risk of sparking controversy, I'd suggest that if we're going to model our missing data semantics on some language's implementation, R is a great choice, particularly if you care about statistical theory (which we should). That said, there are reasonable cases where you might want to do various kinds of comparisons, and the question is really about what we choose to make the default/natural way and then making the other ways possible somehow.
[~npr] I think you're talking about something different. In Arrow NaN is actually not-a-number, not null (which is the most similar concept to R's NA). NumPy has no missing values at all

Right; I was under the impression that {{NaN}} was (also) commonly used to indicate missing values in numpy because it doesn't have a separate missing value. Maybe that was mistaken.

FTR, here's the R example with NaN. Same behavior as with NA:
{code:java}
> NaN == NaN 
[1] NA 
> a <- c(1, NaN, 3, 4) 
> a == a 
[1] TRUE   NA TRUE TRUE 
> identical(a, a) 
[1] TRUE
{code}
I still think we need to clearly distinguish "data structure equality" from "semantic equality". For example, "semantic equality" is probably better addressed by kernels ({{(a == b).all()}})
This has also come up in a slightly different context (comparing {{NaN}}s to non-missing values) and I made ARROW-13364, though depending on how this ticket is resolved they might go together.

As mentioned in that other ticket, I think we should keep discussing them separately. Using the terminology of Wes' last comment, this issue is (originally) about "data structure equality" (do these objects contain equivalent data? i.e. {{arr1.equals(arr2) = True or False}}), while the other is about "semantic/analytical equality" (or comparisons in general, i.e. the comparison compute kernels).
We should first expose the {{EqualOptions}} members as keyword-only arguments in the various {{equals}} methods.
